Taken together, we argue that the results suggest that
structured arts activities does lead to improved transferable skills compared to non
3.5.1 Does participation in structured arts activities improve self
Four studies (three carried out in the
USA and one in Canada) investigated the impact of
participating in arts activities on students
i.e., views about oneself that predict
motivation and performance to varying degrees. One study was rated Medium/High overall
ce (Freeman, 2001) and three were rated Medium (Catterall, 2007; Catterall
Gempton et al., 1999). Three studies included only primary
school children and one study (Catterall, 2007) investigated outcomes for students attendi
The study by Catterall (2007) examined the impact of a school
which used a range of activities,
including attending a professional play, as building bl
ocks for students to write and perform
4). The dissertation study by Freeman (2001) investigated
activities within a school context. Catterall and
children in two major US cities. At one site, the activities were drawing, painting and sculpting,
and at the other site the programme involved creating visual art and writing poetry.
